title: meghan markle prince harry cotswolds move
story: The Duke and Duchess of Sussex took up a two-year lease on the four-bed converted farmhouse before their wedding last year.But they have apparently struggled to afford the upkeep on the Grade II-listed country retreat, the Daily Mail reported.A source told the paper the royal couple have found it dficult to pay the upkeep of two properties, especially while £million building works are underway at Frogmore Cottage in Berkshire.Harry and Meghan will have to pay for the fixtures and fittings, with taxpayers footing the rest of the bill.But the Daily Mail also reported a separate source said the move was due to security reasons.Meghan and Harry were said to have regarded the Cotswolds bolthole as more of a home than Harry’s former Nottingham Cottage bachelor pad in Kensington Palace.A friend of the royal couple said of their countryside home: “It’s a fabulous place with stunning views and extraordinarily private.“It’s set in a small bowl of beautul countryside so is not overlooked in any way.“Meghan adores the area. She and Harry love walking the dogs there, and they can entertain their friends in complete solitude.”They have used the retreat to host a number of A-list pals including George and Amal Clooney, Serena Williams and husband Alexis Ohanian plus Priyanka Chopra and her hubby Nick Jonas.Meghan’s mum Doria Ragland has also visited the bolthole, set in four acres of rolling Cotswolds hills near the trendy private members’ retreat Soho Farmhouse.It was thought that the couple, who are expecting their first child in April, would keep the house on after moving to Frogmore Cottage on the Queen’s Windsor estate this spring.But despite their love for the former farmhouse, they are understood to have cancelled the lease early and are planning to move out in March.The hideaway was leased to them by David Camerons property tycoon pal Nicholas Johnston.The farmhouse, which dates from the th century, has four bedrooms with one converted to a dressing room.An attached converted barn includes an “upper kitchen” and “lower kitchen” plus a sitting area with floor-to-ceiling windows.There is a large dining room plus an outdoor seating area with patio heaters.And the house comes with a two-bedroom cottage for guests or staff.

title: jeremy corbyn walkout second brexit vote
story: Several shadow cabinet ministers fear alienating their Leave votersthe party u-turned into a second Brexit vote, it was revealed today.Some said they would have to quit their own jobs in order to make sure their voters backed them in the next election,said.One told the paper: I would be in a really dficult positionwe backed a second referendum. I would have little choice but to stand downI was to have any hope of retaining my seat and representing my constituents.Another said they were deeply uncomfortable about a so-called Peoples Vote as they promised in their last election to honour the  result.This concept of blocking Brexit is wrong and would break a link with millions of our traditional voters who expect us to keep our word, they said.Labour chair Ian Lavery is said to be sceptical of another vote, and others in Northern seats.Jon Trickett could also be at risk as his Wakefield constituency opted to leave.Last night Diane Abobott warned Labour MPs that Leave would win AGAIN in a referendum and they should be careful what they wish for. MPs have so far come out in favour of a fresh vote.Today one of his own frontbenchers, Rosena Allin-Khan, told the Evening Standard that Mr Corbyn must become the leading voice on the issue, and that his calls for a general election have been flat out rejected.It comes after she attended a Peoples Vote rally last month - but hasnt been dropped from Mr Corbyns top team.She said: Labour members and supporters are looking for Labour to show leadership... Jeremy can really shape what the referendum would look like.Meanwhile, thousands of Labours members have been pressuring him to hold one too.They think it would provide the chance for Britain to stay in the EU altogether.This week Mr Corbyn rejected talks with Theresa May over Brexit, saying that he would only engagethey promised to stop a No Deal.And a group of Tory Remainers launched a fresh bid for a second referendum.But Mr Corbyn is still arguing for an election, because he thinks thats the best way of taking power and keeping his supporters onside.

title: theresa may is prepared to ditch her brexit promises to get a deal signed minister says
story: Prisons minister Rory Stewart said last night thatother parties were serious about doing a deal then they could work together.But he wouldnt compromise on immigration and freedom of movement, he added, because British voters wanted to see that change.He said on BBC Question Time: Freedom of movement would be the most important red line here. The other stuff you could compromise on.However, the PM would only consider doing thisshe could trust that other politicians would back her, he stressed.If they are serious then of course we can sht red lines.But he also warned: You have to make sure whatever youre doing is still recognisably a Brexit deal.You cant water this down so much that doesnt resemble what they voted for at all.Mr Stewart suggested that Brexiteers like Jacob Rees Mogg should be prepared to put down in writing what he would be prepared to do to vote for the deal - which would strengthen Mrs Mays hand in Brussels.Last night Diane Abbott told Question Time that Labour could also be prepared to compromise too - but ONLYMrs May took No Deal off the table.The Shadow Home Secretary said that her party was prepared to be flexible on everything to get a deal that MPs could support.What we want is a deal which is in the best interests of the entire country, she added.Labour has said they want a customs arrangement with the EU when we leave.But Trade Secretary Liam Fox came out earlier today to say that would not deliver Brexit.The UK couldnt do trade deals with other countries around the worldwe were tied to the EUs customs union.Many MPs think there could be a majority in the House of Commons for such a deal.The Prime Minister has been in a frantic round of talks with her ministers today over what to do next to solve the Brexit deadlock.Brexiteers Penny Mordaunt and Michael Gove were seen coming out of Downing Street this afternoon.And the PM spoke on the phone with Donald Tusk and Jean Claude Juncker this afternoon to discuss her next steps.She then left No to spend the weekend at Chequers and work out her Plan B for Brexit.Meanwhile senior DUP sources were said to have warmed to the idea of staying in a customs union with the EU - story: Dutch PM Mark Rutte warned his country’s firms to “prepare for the worst” following a phone call with the PM on Thursday night.And Germany’s foreign Minister Heiko Mass said Angela Merkel had told the PM she was “very clear” the Brexit agreement can’t be changed.It came with just eight days for Mrs May to save Brexit with a Plan B that can secure a Commons majority on January .In another day of dramatic developments yesterday…Theresa May suffered the biggest Commons defeat in history on Tuesday when her Brexit deal was rejected by a thumping  votes.But arch Eurosceptics yesterday held out hope she could win back Tory MPs by reopening the deal to mody demands over the backstop.Under the backstop, the UK and Northern Ireland would be tied to EU customs rules until a new trade agreement is signed. title: how brexiteers celebrated defeating theresa
story: NewsAnalysisHow Brexiteer Tories celebrated with champagne at Jacob Rees-Moggs £m mansionJacob Rees-Mogg celebrated with some of the  revolting MPs at his opulent home after inflicting the biggest Tory rebellion in historyShareCommentsByPippa Crerar:,  JAN NewsAnalysisJacob Rees-Mogg opening the door to guests on Tuesday night - who received a glass of champagne "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailWithin hours of inflicting the biggest defeat in modern history on Tuesday night, hardline Brexiteers’ champagne corks were popping. Jacob Rees-Mogg invited leading Tory eurosceptics including Boris Johnson, David Davis and Iain Duncan Smith to a celebration party. Guests were greeted with a champagne flute at the door of the Tory MP’s pound million mansion just minutes from the House of Commons. The other side of Westminster, Theresa May was contemplating her humiliating defeat and steeling herself for another tumultous day ahead. Her strategy for surviving the no confidence vote was to make sure she didn’t take the fizz out of the Brexiteers champagne too early.   Instead, she waited until after the result was announced by her chief whip before inviting Jeremy Corbyn and other party leaders to talks. But before they even made it to the steps of Downing Street she had scuppered any attempts at compromise by ruling out a customs union. It is Labour’s biggest ask - and would infuriate hardline Brexiteers - but is also one of the few plan Bs that could command a majority in Parliament.  Instead - as the clock ticks ever close to crashing out of the EU without a deal - more stalemate beckons. Over the next few days the PM will try to win over the leaders of smaller parties and backbench Labour MPs. But her refusal to even countenance budging on her red lines suggests she is putting the Tory party ahead of the national interest. She has just four days to try to reach agreement. At that point the Government will have to table a fresh motion which - crucially - can be amended by MPs.   Parliament will take control of Brexit with a series of votes on their own alternatives. Pro-EU MPs are expected to demand the Government rules out a no deal, delays Brexit or holds a second referendum. Even though the votes would not be legally binding, it would be politically impossible for the PM to ignore them. With a softer - and delayed - Brexit looking the most likely outcome, perhaps the champagne should have been kept on ice.

title: you love britain you should
story: NewsopinionIf you love Britain, you should bin BrexitNationalism isnt the same as patriotism - and the zealots are killing our countryShareCommentsByFleet Street FoxColumnist:,  JAN Updated:,  JAN Newsopinion"Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email After inflicting the worst Parliamentary defeat in history and all but derailing the Brexit this nation voted for, a group of elitist plotters met in the heart of the metropolitan bubble this week for backslapping and a champagne celebration.Bizarrely, this group consider themselves patriots. For destabilising the government, damaging democracy, ignoring the will of the people, and hurling us all into an unwanted unknown. And no, theyre not Remainers.This drinks party from hell included household names who, were they living in Hackney, would have been given ASBOs by now. Boris Whose We Is It Anyway Johnson, John Be-Knighted Redwood, David I Can Kill With My Bare Hands, You Know Davis and Iain Universal Credit Was A Great Idea, Wasnt It Duncan Smith.These low-rent conmen, who couldnt sell you a used car without slashing the tyres first, wrap themselves in the Union flag and say they are serving our country while their actions undermine and destroy everything we hold dear.Brexit, they tell us, is vital to democracy, freedom, and the right of Parliament to pass its own laws. So they ignore the will of the people in  and demand we adhere to the will they had in  they demand we unshackle our nation from freedom-loving neighbours and tie it instead to the fate of an orange madman and they fulminate that Parliament passing its own laws is now our biggest fear. And while they strut across our national stage saying No Deal is a great idea, and we should rely on World Trade Organisation rules which would put tarfs on things that currently dont have any, terry the City and mean Northern Ireland gets a Trumpian wall built along its entire , they forget the fact the people not only didnt vote for it, but were expressly told by the Leave campaign it would NEVER happen. There are two main dferences between patriotism and nationalism - thought and effect. Patriotism requires you to put your countrys needs before your personal wishes, so the country wins. Nationalism promises that whatever you wish MUST be delivered because of which rocks you stand on. And the effect of nationalism is always failure. It failed in Ireland. It failed in Germany. It failed in France, Italy, Cambodia, China. It failed in Cable Street. Because nationalism wants, creates and fosters stupidity, those countries which fall victim to it always suffer. To be a nationalist, you have to look at the problems around you and decide its someone s fault. Patriots look at the mess and decide to clean it up. Unfortunately, there arent enough patriots to go around at present.  Theresa May leads the first government in history to be held in contempt of Parliament. For two and a half years, she has put the needs of her party above those of her country. She called a snap election to refresh her popular mandate, and lost it. She has never sought genuine cross-party support for the most serious constitutional decision in our letimes. Instead she is an ideologue interested only in serving the % of the country she thinks is the most racist. Jeremy Corbyn holds a chunk of his own party and voters in contempt, and they hold him in the same. Instead of offering a solution for Brexit, he keeps calling for a general election he doesnt want and cannot win. He has ignored the democratic will of his party and MPs on Brexit because it does not chime with his own wishes, and when asked to talk about Brexit he demands, in effect, that Brexit be stopped first. And this even though he doesnt want it stopped and knows that, politically, it cant be. And around these two in Parliament are others who lack love for their country. MPs who voted resoundingly to begin Article  without a plan in place. Who voted for a referendum that was not binding, and which they now insist must be implemented. Who wrote legislation for that referendum so poor that even after we learned electoral law was broken, we were unable to declare it null and start again. The referendum was always advisory, not legally binding. That meant that even though the Electoral Commission found evidence of tampering at the criminal level of being beyond any reasonable doubt, the referendum could stand. Had the thing carried legal weight, the courts would have cancelled it and ordered another. Although the referendum was badly-legislated and badly-worded - the UK leaving the EU was never an option, only the UK dissolving itself and THEN leaving - no-one working at the heart of our democracy had the wit to write it properly, or the patriotism to put our need for a democratically-reliable vote above their political whim.Because without a legal need to do so, the only reason to enforce the referendum result is political. It depends on the mood of the country. And the mood of the country is a long way from criminals in hi-vis jackets poncing around Parliament Green on a livestream. The country is tired of this. It wants normal and calm and for Parliament to find the time and inclination to fold social care into the NHS, relieve the never-ending winter crisis, fund schools properly, fix the potholes and empty the bins. The nation wants Universal Credit to be fixed, HS to be scrapped and Northern Ireland not to get too excited. But this gravity well at the heart of Westminster is sucking the patriotism, the common sense, and the long-sightedness out of our Parliamentarians. Instead too many of them are manoeuvring for Mays job, while not wanting to do it. Labour is fighting itself, the Lib Dems are barely inhaling and the DUP is giddily running the show despite the fact it is in charge of Northern Ireland only by dint of .% of the vote and couldnt run a tap without screaming. However you voted, you know this: this is not our country at its finest.  The nationalists at Jacob Rees-Moggs soiree have ensured that Theresa May is their leader for another year, but that her plan for Brexit has failed. Parliamentarians have ignored the national will for an orderly Brexit, and the PM has ignored the need for compromise while the unionists of the DUP have done more to dissolve the union than the equivalent amount of hydrochloric acid. And meanwhile, here are we: blaming David Cameron for the mess we voted for him to get us into, arguing over what a badly-written and illegal vote meant, fretting about things which a large chunk of us refuse even to try to understand, and telling pollsters well go for No Deal Because Thats What We Voted For even though a quick look proves that we didnt. If we push on with Brexit, itll be delayed or disastrous. That doesnt suit anyone, Leave, Remain, nationalist or patriot. The costs will be immediate, the trade talks will last for years, and the blame will be apportioned for a century. No-one, but no-one, will win. But what happenswe bin it

title: boy 4 found busy road
story: NewsBoy, , found in busy road after leaving school unnoticed as dad demands answersThe four-year-old pupils dad said he felt physically sick that staff at Forest Lodge Academy, in Leicester, had allowed his son to wander out of the school gatesShareCommentsByDave Owen:,  JAN NewsThe school said it was making enforced, proactive improvements to prevent any repeat of the incident "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA boy was nearly knocked over trying to cross a busy main road after he managed to leave his school unnoticed. The four-year-old pupil wandered out of Forest Lodge Academy, in Leicester, under the noses of teachers and support staff. One driver said she had to slam the brakes to avoid running him down on a busy main road. The incident took place at the end of the school day at around pm yesterday. The boys dad, who wants to remain anonymous, said he felt “physically sick” that it was allowed to happen. Now he is demanding answers from the school. He told Leicestershire Live: “It was at the end of the school day and when parents and s were collecting the children.   “Somehow my son, who is only four, managed to walk out of the school past teachers and school staff. “He wandered out of the door and out of the school gates. “He’d managed to cross one road and was trying to cross Charnor Road, which is very busy at that time of day, when a woman picking up her child spotted him. “She had to slam on her brakes to avoid hitting him and got out and grabbed him. “It wasn’t until that point that anyone realised he was gone.” The boy had been waiting along with other pupils to be collected from school when he went walkabout. His father said: “His aunt was picking him from school. She had parked nearby and was walking through a jitty when she saw a commotion in the road ahead of her. “All the cars had stopped and there was a crowd gathered around. “It wasn’t until she got closer that she realised it was my son who was involved.   “He was unhurt but it could’ve been so much worse. “The driver said she felt sick – I feel sick too that this was allowed to happen. It’s disgraceful.” He added: “I was at work when my ex-partner rang me about  minutes later to tell me what happened. “I wasn’t very happy about it at all. “I rang the school and was told a member of the school staff had been standing at a door reading a roll call. “When a parent arrives to pick up their child then their name is called out. “They said no-one had called out my son’s name so they assumed he was still there.” The school has since issued an apology to the boy’s parents and held a meeting with his mother. His father said: “I want answers. I don’t know how he simply walked out.   “He could have been run over or abducted. And we’d have had no idea. It’s only luck that prevented it from turning out very dferently.” He added: “I want assurances that it will not happen again. “When you send your child to school you expect every precaution to be taken to make sure they are safe.” A statement issued by the school said it was making “enforced, proactive improvements” to increase security and prevent any repeat of the incident. Headteacher Claire Caldwell said: “An incident took place after school on Thursday that was resolved quickly and effectively - of which we immediately informed the mother of the child. “Following this, and in line with good practice, we informed all necessary authorities and a full staff briefing was held where a thorough risk assessment and review of the relevant policies was completed. “We have already made and enforced proactive improvements and processes moving forwards.” She added: “A full face to face meeting was held this morningwith the mother where all of this was comprehensively outlined and acknowledged. “As always, the safety of our whole school community is of paramount importance to us.”

title: boy 4 who couldnt swim
story: NewsBoy, , who couldnt swim found floating after dad left him alone at water parkThe boy was found floating under the water by a female swimmer in the adult pool in Burnham on Crouch, SomersetShareByMartyn HalleAbigail OLeary:,  JAN Updated:,  JAN NewsThe horric incident occurred at Brean Leisure Park in Burnham on Crouch, Somerset"Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA four-year-old boy almost drowned after his father left him alone in a toddler pool to go on a water slide. The father, who cannot be named for legal reasons, was slammed by a judge for leaving his son alone for a momentary frolic. The boy was left alone in a special toddler part of the pool at Brean Leisure Park in Burnham on Crouch, Somerset, before he made his way into the adult pool. He was found floating under the water by a female swimmer who felt her foot brush against something on the bottom. The father had taken the boy swimming after an argument with his former partner and forgot to take his sons armbands. He was charged with causing unnecessary suffering of a child under  following the incident in August . Emma Martin, prosecuting at Taunton Crown Court, said: This was a tragic case of a momentary error of judgement on the defendants part.He didnt take arm bands with him knowing full well that his son couldnt swim.   He went with his son to the small toddler area. The defendant decided to go on the flume himself leaving his son to play in the toddler area. By the time he came back his son wasnt where he left him. The court heard the mans son, who was just four and a half at the time of the incident, had climbed out of the small toddler area and gone into the adult pool. Mrs Harding, a swimmer who was in the adult pool at the time of the incident, said she felt her foot brush something during her swim and was shocked when she saw the body of a child floating under the water. Mrs Martin said Mrs Harding pulled the boy to safety and put him on the side of the pool but leguards and swimmers were shocked and didnt know what to do so the boy lay motionless on the side of the pool for a few minutes. The court heard off duty paramedic Emma Aims then ran over to the scene and started to resuscitate the boy and luckily he regained consciousness after coughing up a large amount of water. The boy was taken to Bristol Childrens Hospital for treatment and stayed in their high dependency unit for two days.   The court heard when the father called his former partner to tell her what had happened he lied he had just popped to the toilet when the incident happened and also lied when interviewed by police. Mrs Martin said the man later called the police and admitted he had left the child unattended and said the son has made a full recovery.Defending, Charlotte Pitts said the defendant and his former partner broke up shortly after the incident but said he managed to rebuild the relationship with his son and sees him on a regular basis. Ms Pitts said the man is deeply remorseful for his actions and said references describe him as a great father and friend. Sentencing, Judge David Ticehurst, said: This must have been any parents nightmare. What was wrong as you may realise was to leave your son for a momentary frolic and forget about him.  If you had just turned awaynone of this would have happened, your son wouldnt have had to spent two days in hospital. I have no doubt that you feel remorse after this incident. Any parent could go and do something with their children and think,only I had taken things a bit more carefully. Dont you dare leave him alone again. Judge Ticehurst sentenced the man to an  month conditional discharge and ordered that pound of public money be given to Mrs Harding and Emma Aims to recognise the efforts they made in rescuing the boy. He was also ordered to pay pound in costs including pound to the two ladies who saved his sons le.

title: commuters driving work busy cities
story: NewsCommuters driving to work in busy cities could be forced to pay £,-a-yearThe AA have slammed the charge as a poll tax on wheels and warned the costs of the annual workplace parking levy will be passed onto workersShareCommentsByTom DavidsonOnline Reporter:,  JAN NewsHeavy traffic on the Tyne Bridge into Newcastle "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailCommuters who drive to work in busy cities could have to pay pound, a year as part of new plans to drive down congestion, it has been reported. The new charge is aimed at freeing up roads in some of the UKs busiest cities.A workplace parking levy is being considered by at least ten councils in England and Scotland to reduce traffic and pollution and to raise money for public transport, according to The Times.The charge would be imposed on businesses with more than ten parking spaces and is designed to push employees out of their cars. The AA told the newspaper that the plans were a “poll tax on wheels” and that costs would be passed onto workers.   In Nottingham, the only city to introduce the levy so far, about four in ten companies pass costs on to staff, it has been reported. Hundreds of teachers pay to park cars in the city but NHS buildings are exempt. The charge has raised pound.million since it was introduced in , with much of that money being spent on improving the citys tram network. However critics have claimed there is little evidence that the levy had in fact cut car journeys and have warned they could lead to job losses.   Robert Halfon, Conservative chairman of the Commons education select committee, told The Times: “This is complete madness. It’s yet another tax on motorists and all it will do is hit working people with the cost of living. It’s entirely the wrong thing to do.” Hounslow in west London is proposing to charge between pound and pound, a year per parking space.  A consultation closed on Friday and the plans will be examined by the council’s cabinet. At least nine other councils are pushing for the levy, according to The Times. Edinburgh and Glasgow councils have declared their intention to introduce a charge.Reading, Oxford, Bristol land Cambridge and the London boroughs of Merton, Brent and Camden are consulting on introducing them.

title: dancing ice didi conn cried
story: NewsDancing on Ice Didi Conn cried when autistic son first said I love you age EXCLUSIVE: Grease star Didi, , took years out of her career to give round-the clock care to Danny, who was diagnosed aged three and cannot be left aloneShareCommentsByJulie McCaffrey:,  JAN NewsDidi with husband David and Danny"Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailHearing her son say “I love you” for the first time made Dancing on Ice star Didi Conn cry tears of joy. That’s because the shyemotional moment came only weeks ago – and her son Danny is  years old. For a young man with autism, who struggles to understand abstract ideas and emotions, it was a major breakthrough. Didi says: “The first time Danny said, ‘I love you’ was this year. I was leaving to fly to the UK and he said it on the phone. I kept saying, ‘say it again, baby’. And he did. “Then he said, ‘why are you crying ’. So I told him they were happy tears. And oh my God, did I cry  It was the biggest milestone, it really was. Because I couldn’t really hold him as a baby, as he was so sensitive and didn’t like to be held, so that was tricky. It really was something special to hear.” Grease star Didi, , took years out of her career to give round-the clock care to Danny, who was diagnosed aged three and has extreme sensitivity to sound and cannot be left alone. She agreed to leave her New York home for her new Dancing on Ice role only after he settled happily into le on a self-sustaining farm and school supported by -hour carers. The move springboards her to the second chapter of her career. And although younger contestants are scoring higher marks, thoughts of her son help boost her confidence.  Didi says: “When I saw a film of my first dress rehearsal on the ice, I was upset because I didn’t look good and everybody  seemed to be much better skaters. “I was feeling stressed so I meditated and what came to my mind was how accepting we are of Daniel and his limitations. You go into another time zone when you are a parent of an autistic child, where any micro movement in a positive direction is such a cause for celebration. “That’s a gt, because children can grow so quickly and we don’t see every incremental change. “Then I have to give myself a break, put things in perspective and realise I am doing more than I did two months ago. I didn’t fall down.” Didi, who has been married to composer David Shire for  years, will for ever be remembered as Frenchy in Grease, the biggest musical film of the th century. She played a teenage beauty-school dropout, but in reality she was  and ending her first marriage to Frankie Conn when the film was released in .   Didi performed her first Dancing on Ice routine in her original Pink Ladies jacket, which she only realised was valuable after hearing about the one belonging to co-star Dinah Manoff, who played Marty Maraschino in the film. “TV producers told me they once had to insure Marty’s jacket for pound,. Mine’s just been on a hanger next to all my ordinary clothes all these years.”Judge Jason Gardiner was witheringly unimpressed with her routine to film track We Come Together and accused her of “dining out on that song for years”. Didi says: “I wasn’t hurt by Jason’s comments because he’s a nice guy. But my husband got a copy of the episode and showed it to my three brothers. They were upset by his words, so that upset me. “Actually, my brothers might fly over and have a bit of a word with Jason.”  Didi’s Grease co-star John Travolta might also be pretty mfed with Jason. Ever since starring in the global hit, the pair have remained firm friends.Didi’s bond with Travolta, , grew even stronger when his son Jett, who died in , aged , after suffering a seizure, was diagnosed with autism. “His son Jett was six months older than Daniel and he was diagnosed with autism, but they didn’t want to call it that when he was alive. “After he passed away they said yes, it was autism. He was so concerned and I would talk with his we about it. “I know they invested millions of dollars into dferent research because Jett did not speak. Anything I ever heard about new findings, whether it was diet or anything, they would follow up.”  Didi says she is in touch with everyone from Grease, including Barry Pearl, but not Stockard Channing, and is very close to Olivia Newton-John, . She was stunned when news spread that the star, who has breast cancer, is close to death. Didi says: “That was a terrible shock. Someone told me they’d just heard this awful rumour. But I’d just talked to her two days before and she sounded fine. “Then they showed me the video of her saying she was well and she looked beautul. So I called her right afterwards and she said, ‘you know how these rumours start’. She’s very well.” For now, Didi is looking ahead to tomorrow’s show when she and her professional skating partner Lukasz Rozycki will perform to the Mary Poppins song Spoonful of Sugar.  She says: “My shoulders keep coming up when I skate, but that’s a lot to do with being  and you start to get a hump. “But Mary Poppins is so elegant she would never have her shoulders up. So it’s a great challenge...” Look closely at Didi’s costume and you might see the outline of a secret gadget she created to help her through rehearsals. “I made an invention,” she says. “One place I don’t have a lot of padding is my ribs. A little further down’s fine. I’m learning new lts and my ribs were very sore. “So I got knee pads, brought them to the wardrobe department and they extended the elastic so they go around my waist and protect my ribs.  “And they really help – just don’t tell anybody.” This series of Dancing on Ice, hosted by Holly Willoughby and Phillip Schofield, has been rocked with controversy after Holly accused contestant Gemma Collins of being unprofessional for holding up filming by leaving early because she was bored. Didi is diplomatic. “If Gemma held up filming, I wasn’t there. If someone had that experience, it wasn’t me. “Gemma was up on the balcony cheering me when I did my first skate – and that helped me so much. “Every time I pass her, she’s doing something on her phone and she says, ‘oh, there’s my Didi’. She’s always so loving. “She’s a beautul, golden Mae West. She’s so sexy and funny and really knows how to hold an audience, which is a beautul thing to see. She sparkles.”  For Grease-lovers, there is only one legend on the show and it’s Didi. For  years, fans across the world have adored her portrayal of Pink Lady Frenchy and it’s clear Didi also has huge affection for the character.Didi is touched by the outpouring of love for her on Twitter , but says there are some drawbacks to being so well remembered.“My voice triggers people into recognising me, often at the weirdest times. If I’m in the theatre and talking while in line to go to the loo, the rest of the queue will turn around and say, ‘wait a minute, it’s you’. “Then they try to talk to me when I’m about to go into the stall. And that’s not a good place to talk.”

title: healthy mum seven 34 suddenly
story: NewsHealthy mum-of-seven, , suddenly drops dead from silent killer in her homeLoyal and loving Jacqueline Totty, of Wirral, Merseyside, died after suffering from a rare heart disease she was not even aware she hadShareCommentsByRachael McMenemy:,  JAN NewsJacqueline Ann Totty, , died from a rare form of heart disease "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA mum-of-seven who appeared to be perfectly healthy dropped dead at her home from a silent killer. Jacqueline Ann Totty, , suffered from a rare heart disease which saw her collapse and fall of a chair at her home. Her fiance, Paul Tippins, started CPR while he waited for an ambulance to arrive at the property in Wirral, Merseyside. Liverpool Echo reports that despite being rushed to Arrowe Park Hospital all attempts to resuscitate her failed. Jacqueline died on September , , Liverpool Coroners Court was told. In a tribute posted on a Just Giving page the mum was described as a loyal, loving partner shortly after her death. Pathologist, Dr Christopher Johnson, warned her family of the dangers of the rare inherited heart disease, that killed her during an inquest into her death. Arrhythmogenic Cardiomyopathy is known to cause sudden death, especially in younger people.   Dr Johnson also told the court toxicology results showed Miss Totty had a small amount of cocaine in her system. However he did not believe this to be a signicant factor in her death. He said: I felt these changes [to her heart] were more extensive that just previous cocaine use.I asked for a specialist opinion to have this reviewed with particular concern about her age and something going on with her heart. However, he said he could not discard the cocaine entirely, telling the court:Both can cause abnormalities , together its not a good combination.   A tribute on a Just Giving Page to help with funeral costs said: Jackie was only  and a loving mum of seven.She was a loyal loving partner to her fianceacute Paul and was so excited to get married. She had a heart of gold and would do anything for youyou asked.Shes had a tough time over the years, but she managed to pull herself back with a little help from her family and friends, back to where she needed to be in le but sadly that le has been taken away from her.   Coroner Anita Bhardwaj said: On September ,  she was admitted [to Arrowe Park Hospital] after she was seen to fall back off a chair and became unresponsive and suffered cardiac arrest. She added: She died of the natural disease Arrhythmogenic Cardiomyopathyin conjunction with cocaine.In its own right it can cause sudden death, more than likely a combination of both has increased the risk of fatality. The coroner also urged Miss Tottys family to consider being tested for the rare disease that killed her, especially her children.

story: NewsLandlord branded despicable for homophobic Gumtree advert for room to rentTwitter users have slammed a landlords homophobic ad that was listed on GumtreeShareCommentsByRobyn DarbyshireAudience Writer:,  JAN NewsThe now-deleted listing for a property in south west London has been slammed "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA landlord has been criticised on social media after a Gumtree user spotted a homophobic advert for a rental flat in London. The ad reads that the house is occupied by young, friendly and quiet housemates and is suitable for couples, students or professionals. However, the ad explicitly states that gay lesbian, pets, children, smoking are strictly not allowed. Under the Equality Act , discriminating against anyone because of their sexual orientation is illegal.   People on Twitter have condemned the landlords actions, slamming them as despicable and disgusting.One wrote: This cannot be legal #equalityall. A third wrote: Id rather know that theyre a homophobic dinosaur before I handed over any monies OR moved in!A spokesperson for Gumtree said to Mail Online: In line with the Equalities Act, we do not allow any unlawful or discriminatory ads on Gumtree.Any ads that discriminate against potential tenants based on age, disability, gender, race, religion or belief, or sexual orientation will be removed. story: NewsPrince Philip cried Im a fool as he was pulled from windscreen of Land RoverThe Duke of Edinburgh, , was yesterday involved in a two-vehicle collision yesterday near the Queens Sandringham Estate in NorfolkShareCommentsByBradley Jolly:,  JAN Updated:,  JAN NewsPrince Philip was involved in a car crash near the Queens Sandringham Estate "Get Royal Family updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailPrince Philip said Im such a fool after he was pulled from the wreckage of his Land Rover, a witness tonight claims.Shocked onlookers described the horror at seeing the dukes car collide into a blue Kia near the Queens Sandringham Estate in Norfolk. story: NewsPrince Philip rushed to askmum and baby were safe after horror car crashThe -year-old Duke was driving on a country road near Sandringham, Norfolk, when he had an accident with a Kia carrying two women and a -month-old babyShareCommentsByAbigail OLeary:,  JAN Updated:,  JAN Newsthis.style.displaynone"Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror video duke-edinburgh-involved-road-traffic-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news uk-news  , theme : # , title : Mirror UK News ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,swipeNavigation:true,info:,article:,info:,],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news uk-news  , theme : # , title : Mirror UK News ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,swipeNavigation:true""Get Royal Family updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailPrince Philip rushed to aska mother and baby involved in last nights crash were safe after he was pulled from the mangled wreckage of his vehicle.The -year-old Duke was driving his Land Rover on a country road near Sandringham, Norfolk, when he collided with a Kia carrying two women and a -month-old baby. Roy Warne, , was a witness to the crash and first on the scene. Asked what the Duke first said when he was freed, he replied: I cant remember, but it was nothing rude. He was obviously shaken, and then he went and askedeveryone  was all right. Barrister Roy added the Dukes first words to him while he lay trapped were: My legs, where should I put my legs . He described seeing the Land Rover roll across the A like a somersault, adding it was turning on its side over and over, reports The Sun. Roy, who was travelling with his we Victoria at the time, stopped his car and rushed to help, eventually pulling the Duke from his seat after smashing through the windscreen and sunroof.   He revealed how Prince Philip said the Duke went on to ask where to , when Roy told him to move one of his legs to free the other. He was disorientated and humbled. I believe he was very sorry about what had happened. He was very shaken and then he went and askedeveryone  was alright. Roy revealed how he first attended the passengers and baby in the blue Kia, saying how he thought it was going to burst into flames when he saw smoke rising from it.   He said he could hear a baby screaming in the back of the car and that his mother was understandably hysterical. Roy told Radio  Today: The person in the car behind me also stopped and a passenger from that car actually took the baby in his arms after we had freed it from the baby harness. One of them had a broken arm. They were very shaken. One of them was the mother of the child and she was quite upset. I think theres no doubt that it was hit . Thats my recollection. I didnt see it come from the side road, I saw it careering and tumbling across the road and ending up on the other side. It would take a massive force and it had rolled on the other side as well. Roy also told the Sun how the Duke, who escaped without serious injury, had been dazzled by the sun.  The glare of the low-lying sun can be a particular problem for drivers at certain times of year. According to the AA, being dazzled by bright light is frequently cited as the cause of road accidents. Figures released in  showed the glare of a low-lying sun was contributing to an average of  road deaths a year. Two women required hospital treatment after the crash, with one suspected of suffering a broken arm. The full statement from Buckingham Palace, released yesterday, reads: The Duke of Edinburgh was involved in a road traffic accident with another vehicle this afternoon. The Duke was not injured. The accident took place close to the Sandringham Estate.   A police spokesman said: “We were called to the scene at around pm to reports of a two vehicle collision. The road is not blocked. Recovery has been called and we are at the scene waiting for them to arrive.” Norfolk Police is investigating the incident and a full investigation is taking place, it is understood.

title: sas legend chris ryan delves
story: NewsSAS legend Chris Ryan on the crack units finest hours after soldiers fearless heroism in KenyaWhen an SAS soldier heard about the terror attack in Nairobi he stormed the luxury Dusit complex single-­handedly to tackle terrorist gunmen and lead terried hostages to safetyShareCommentsByMatt RoperMatt Roper:,  JAN Updated:,  JAN NewsA raid at the Iranian Embassy in May  "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe astonishing pictures of an SAS man taking on terrorists in Kenya this week offer a very rare glimpse of the crack unit. Although not part of an official mission, it showed off the skill and heroism that has made the regiment admired by armies around the world. But most of its exploits will never be told as it prides itself on secrecy. The soldier, in Kenya training the country’s own special forces, was said to be out shopping when al-Shabaab fighters targeted a hotel. He sprinted back to his car to kit-up and then waded in, storming the luxury Dusit complex in Nairobi single-shyhandedly to tackle terrorist gunmen and leading terried hostages to safety.   The astonishing images rank alongside the famous footage of the regiment taking the Iranian Embassy in West London in , where  hostages were being held. Here, SAS legend Chris Ryan, who spent  years in the regiment and walked  miles to the Syrian border in the Gulf War to escape Iraqi forces, tells of a few of its finest hours… Afghanistan, January   When a Taliban commander escaped a joint British and Afghan special forces raid and disappeared into a narrow mountain tunnel, an SAS soldier volunteered to go in after him alone. Afghan soldiers had refused to enter the terrorist-riddled cave complex, where tunnels were barely big enough for a man to fit inside. So the SAS sergeant crawled into the dark tunnel system to locate the enemy fighter. The unnamed -year-old, from the Midlands, eventually found three Taliban soldiers inside the narrow caves and shot them dead with his Glock sidearm. When he saw another, he pointed it towards him but the gun failed. Without enough room for a long-barrelled weapon, he picked up a claw hammer and hit the Taliban soldier over the head. A source said: “He fought two more in the dark where the tunnel opened into a larger room which was partially lit by a candle. “After he killed those two, he was attacked by another but killed him almost instantly with a single blow. It was a brutal fight to the death. “The SAS sergeant emerged from the tunnel half an hour later covered in blood, both his own and those of the men he had killed.” He later said that the minutes he spent inside the caves had been the hardest of his military career. Chris says: “It was an incredible act of bravery, going in to one of the tunnel systems by himself, the claustrophobia, and lack of air – the thought of it is absolutely terrying. “The soldier was so traumatised he was unable to speak for a time after coming out. But his bravery is not extraordinary among SAS soldiers, it’s just what they do.” Lufthansa Flight , October ,   When terrorists hijacked Lufthansa Flight   minutes into its flight from Palma de Mallorca to Frankfurt, German chancellor Helmut Schmidt asked for help from our special forces. SAS veterans Sgt Maj Barry Davies and Maj Alastair Morrison were summoned to Downing Street, where they set about devising a plan to rescue the hostages –  passengers, including  German beauty queens, and five crew. Davies told ministers, as well as German anti-terror unit GSG, an assault using recently developed stun grenades offered the best chance. Over the next few days, they trailed the Boeing  as the four Palestinian terrorists, demanding the release of prisoners in Germany and Turkey, made the pilots fly to airports in Rome, Cyprus, Bahrain, Dubai, Aden, and Mogadishu in Somalia.In Dubai, the SAS and GSG operatives were on the point of making an assault when it took off and flew to Aden – where pilot Jurgen Schumann was shot dead. The co-pilot flew the plane to Mogadishu, where Schumann’s body was dumped on the tarmac and an ultimatum issued for the release of the prisoners. There, Davies and Morrison’s daring plan was put into action. Shortly before midnight, Somali soldiers lit a large bonfire on the runway to create a ersion and draw the hijackers into the cockpit, as the assault team approached the rear. As the emergency doors were blown in, the SAS men hurled stun grenades as German soldiers stormed in, telling hostages to lie down and opening fire. Three terrorists were killed, including the leader, who died before he could detonate the grenades rigged up around the plane. Only four hostages and one German soldier were wounded. Chris says at first, no one knew of the role of the SAS. “Whenever anything happened they were who governments would call first. But often no one found out the SAS were behind them. Even during the Waco siege in the US we had two advisors there. The way the Lufthansa hijacking was carried out follows the textbook to the letter, I’ve taken part in training on planes using exactly the same tactics.” Davies, who died in , was later awarded the British Empire Medal and Morrison the OBE. Malayan Emergency -  Disbanded after the end of the Second World War, the SAS was reformed after communist fighters started a guerrilla war against colonial British rule in Malaya, southeast Asia. The CTs – or communist terrorists – set up bases in the thick jungle and from there attacked police stations, rubber plantations and tin mines. As the brutal attacks escalated, three SAS squadrons – first called the Malayan Scouts – were formed, tasked with taking the fight to the insurgents by operating as guerrillas themselves. Commanded by Maj Mike Calvert, small SAS patrols of  men disappeared deep into the remote jungles for up to three months at a time, in appalling conditions, and soon became skilled in jungle warfare.  One of the tactics of the SAS men was to befriend the jungle tribes who often supplied the terrorists with food, using their medical skills to treat their diseases and even learning to speak their tribal language, Sakai. This way, they were able to cut off the CTs’ supply sources, forcing them to retreat further into the swamps and jungles, where they were hunted down and either killed or captured. Chris Ryan says the Malaya jungle experience served as the basis for SAS tactics to this day. He adds: “Every tactic the SAS usestoday originates in jungle and isthe most important part of soldiers’training. “If you can soldier in the jungle, you can soldier anywhere.” Pebble Island May  to ,   As British troops headed to recapture the Falkland Islands in May , an advance reconnaissance team of SAS troops discovered an Argentine airstrip on Pebble Island. It was feared the Pucara and T- Turbo-Mentor planes stationed there might attack the main British force when it landed at San Carlos. Due to the presence of civilians nearby, an air strike was deemed unsuitable – so a daring SAS mission was quickly planned instead. On the night of May ,  SAS operatives were dropped by helicopter five miles from their target, then marched towards the airstrip. While the destroyer HMS Glamorgan began raining shells on the barracks, two seven-man SAS assault teams made their way to the aircraft, placing the explosive charges on their fuselages. They then retreated and set off the charges, destroying all  planes in a series of explosions. The smouldering wrecks were then raked with machine gun fire and anti-tank rockets to prevent the enemy repairing them or reusing any parts. Fuel spilling on to the airfield then caught fire and the enormous blaze, along with the continued shell and tracer rounds, lit up the night sky. The only SAS casualties were two men lightly injured by a landmine. Chris says: “This raid was classic SAS, just like the regiment’s famous missions blowing up German airfields in Africa during the Second World War. “It’s the kind of mission that makes the SAS feared by any army.” Tragically, just days later, many of the Pebble Island heroes lost their lives in a freak accident considered the biggest SAS catastrophe since the Second World War, when a Sea King helicopter with  people on board crashed after a large sea bird was sucked into its engine. Twenty servicemen were killed,  of them SAS, and most of whom had taken part in the Pebble Island raid.

title: shoreham airshow pilot screamed take
story: NewsShoreham Airshow pilot screamed take me away after horror crash that killed Ex-RAF fighter pilot Andy Hill, , is accused of manslaughter by gross negligence over the crash at the West Sussex airfieldShareByHana Carter:,  JAN NewsA classic s fighter jet plummeted into cars on a busy dual carriageway and exploded "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe pilot who crashed at the Shoreham Airshow screamed in agony, “take me away, take me away” after the horror in which  men died, a court heard yesterday. Andy Hill, , is accused of manslaughter by gross negligence over the crash at the West Sussex airfield. A court heard medics thought Hill was unconscious when they found him lying on the ground without a helmet. But the ex-RAF fighter pilot opened his eyes and, though barely coherent, was able to respond to questions. He was yelling: “Ow, ow, ow” and, “Come on guys, take me away, take me away”, according to a transcript read to the Old Bailey yesterday.  Tony Kemp, a Red Cross nurse, was one of the first medics at the scene and found between  and  people being led away for help. He told the court: “I remember he [Hill] had quite a lot of blood around his face.” The pilot had symptoms consistent with a head injury and his medical condition was deteriorating rapidly, he added.  Jurors heard Hill “collapsed very rapidly” and was at risk of having a cardiac arrest but the team managed to save his le. Mr Kemp told the court Hill was sedated with mg of ketamine and rushed to hospital. Without immediate treatment, he would have died at the scene. The Red Cross nurse told the jury he had to climb through undergrowth to get to the wreckage and could see “a lot of debris” as the blaze from the aircraft raged on August , . Firefighters ran out of water and were soon unable to tackle the flames, the jury was told.  Thomas Maloney, the former owner of the doomed Hawker Hunter fighter jet, earlier told the court how he watched the tragedy in horror. Mr Maloney, a pilot for about  years, said: “At the time I was quite shocked as the air speed was quite slow.”  Mr Maloney, who bought the jet from the Ministry of Defence in , told the court he had a “sickening feeling” and turned to his friend, also a pilot, and, referring to Hill, said: “Well, he’s dead then.” The plane failed to complete a loop and crashed into a “huge fireball” on the A, engulfing spectators and motorists. Four of the  men who died were in their s. Hill of Sandon, Herts, denies manslaughter by gross negligence. His trial continues.

title: speedy prince philip been told
story: NewsSpeedy Prince Philip has been told to give up driving since the sAn excerpt from the biography of Prince Philips valet, John Dean, reveals decades-old concerns about the Dukes driving habitsShareCommentsByLuke Kenton:,  JAN NewsPrince Philip was involved in a frightening crash shortly after his engagement to Queen Elizabeth "Get Royal Family updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailPrince Philip gave aides a royal fright when he crashed his Land Rover on Thursday - but his driving has been reportedly causing concern for decades. In his  book ‘Duke of Edinburgh: A portrait by his valet’, John Dean reveal that shortly after the Elizabeth II and Philip got engaged in , the future prince was involved in a nasty collision. Skidding off the road in Cirencester, Gloucestershire, Philip - who according to Dean was renown for his speed - struck a tree, before crashing through a fence. Then , Prince Philip escaped relatively unscathed, suffering a few bruises and a twisted knee. He was rescued by a passing driver after midnight, who spotted him standing next to the wreckage.   The accident added further public scrutiny on young Philip’s behaviour during a bout of constant publicity after his proposal to the future Queen of England. The Duke of Edinburgh was advised to surrender his license indefinitely, according to Dean. “After the engagement was announced, his private le became so much a public affair that it was even suggested he should give up driving,” Dean recalled. The former valet described Philip’s driving style as “fast but safe” in his experience at the side of the duke.   “He is a very good driver,” Dean said in . The passage also cites a newspaper article from the time, which highlights the Prince’s penchant for speed. It reads: A keen mechanic and motorist, he has a zest for speed which has even upset even the Royal chauffeurs, men with accident-free records who are now chary of driving with him. Philip’s naval friends credit him with their camp record for the ninety-eight-mile journey from Corsham to London one hour forty minutes.  On Thursday, Prince Phillip collided with a blue Kia carrying a -month-old child on board near the Queen’s Sandringham Estate in Norfolk. A passing driver, -year-old Victoria Warne - whose husband helped hoist the -year-old from the wreckage - says Philip asked “Is everyone alright ” Before adding, “I’m such a fool.”  The Duke was treated in hospital on Friday morning, but is understood to have been “worrying about the others [involved in the crash]” Mr Warne said: I saw the car flip and thought f*****g hell. Before I even stopped I said to Victoria, dial . I looked down and had the Prince’s blood on my hands. All I could think is, thank goodness there wasn’t more, the pensioner told The Sun. I had his blood on my hands. It wasn’t much and one of the royal people gave me a wipe.”  The smash injured a grandmother and mum but the baby travelling in the Kia was unharmed. The duke retired from royal duties in August  and underwent a hip replacement in May last year, having completed some , solo engagements since . A Buckingham Palace statement read: The Duke of Edinburgh was involved in a road traffic accident with another vehicle this afternoon. The Duke was not injured. The accident took place close to the Sandringham Estate.” Norfolk Police said the incident would be investigated and any appropriate action taken. Meanwhile measures to reduce the crash road’s speed limit to mph and install cameras were passed. A Norfolk County Council meeting in Norwich heard the stretch had been considered dangerous for some time.

title: vigilante urged catch nonce out
story: NewsVigilante urged to "catch the nonce out" before stabbing child killer to deathDarran Evesham, , Ieuan Harley,  and David Osbourne , are accused of murdering David Gaut, , in New Tredegar, South Wales, after finding out he brutally killed a babyShareByLiz Day:,  JAN NewsA court sketch of the three accused at Cardf Crown Court "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA vigilante received a message urging him to catch the f*****g nonce out before he and two others stabbed a child murderer to death, a court heard. Darran Evesham, , Ieuan Harley,  and David Osbourne, are jointly accused of murdering David Gaut, , after discovering he brutally killed a -month-old baby in . They are alleged to have lured Gaut - who also went by the name Dai - to Osbournes flat in New Tredegar, South Wales, before stabbing him  times and cutting off his finger nails, jurors were told. Newport Crown Court heard a message was sent to Osbourne from witness Kyle Alford, saying: Don’t let Dai know we all know he’s a baby killer. Catch the f***ing nonce out,” reports Wales Online. Mr Alford, Osbournes neighbour, told the court how he wanted nothing to do with setting Gaut up so left the premises before the killing.  Mr Alford also told the court Gaut told people in the community he had been to prison for murdering a solider. In fact, Gaut had served  years in prison for the murdering his girlfriends son, Chi Ming Shek, while babysitting. The babys mum Jane Pickthall, then , had been out drinking and left Gaut to look after her two young children before he battered, kicked and burned the youngster. She arrived home in Caerphilly, South Wales, and made love to Gaut - but the next day she found her sons dead body under a chest of drawers. The court heard how Mr Alford discovered Gaut was convicted for a childs murder, not a soldiers, after searching for his name on Google . He told the jury he felt shocked, disgusted and angry at the discovery and then told his neighbour, Osbourne. Mr Alford said: Osbourne was fuming. Angry. Very angry. Just about wanting to beat him up really. Ozzy made a comment, want to cut him up and chuck him down the plughole or something.  Fellow neighbour Ieuan Harley then became angry at the news - calling Gaut a dirty f***er before allegedly planning his murder. Osbourne is alleged to have lured Gaut to his flat by asking him round to the flat to watch a DVD. There, Osbourne, , Harley, , and Darran Evesham, , are alleged to have stabbed Gaut to death before dragging his dead body back next door and trying to clean up the crime scene. Ben Douglas-Jones, prosecuting, said pathologist Dr Derrick James carried out a post-mortem exam and found at least  stab wounds all over Gauts body from at least one kne and a screwdriver. The prosecutor said: A screwdriver was found in the folds of his dressing gown. The injuries to his neck appear to have been consistent with the screwdriver found in the folds of the dressing gown.  “Many of the stab wounds are consistent with having been made with knives. “Dr James found it may be that a larger blade was used to cause the wounds in the belly. “He had been clearly stabbed many times until he was dead. Even then, he continued to receive stabbing blows. “All three wanted him dead. They encouraged each other and played their parts in the lead-up to the murder.” “Mr James found his finger nails had been cut off after he died. Evesham, Osbourne and Harley, all of New Tredegar, Gwent, deny murder. The trial at Newport Crown Court is expected to last four weeks.

title: what really happened fyre festival
story: NewsWhat really happened at Fyre Festival after it was branded worlds biggest flopA new Netflix documentary Fyre: The Greatest Party That Never Happened is released todayShareCommentsByJane Lavender:,  JAN NewsFyre was billed as a luxury festival "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailIt was supposed to be the most glamorous music festival ever organised.Advertised by A-listers including Hailey Baldwin, Kendall Jenner and Bella Hadid, tickets cost as much as pound,.Held on a deserted island in the Bahamas, Fyre Festival was supposed to be the best in food, art, music and adventure. Festival goers were promised luxury accommodation, gourmet food and the ultime music line-up including Blink , Migos and Major Lazer. But the reality was very dferent.   Instead of luxury, guests were forced to sleep on rain-soaked mattresses, the gourmet food was in fact sandwiches made from cheese slices and luggage was hurled into an unlit car park. Since the debacle in , organiser Billy McFarland has been sentenced to six years in prison for multiple counts of fraud.A new Netflix documentary, Fyre: The Greatest Party That Never Happened, released today, lists the lid on what really happened.Billed as the ultimate millennial experience, people battling for tickets were promised they would be rubbing shoulders with the rich and famous.  But in reality, those who managed to bag a ticket for the hottest party in town said most people were as ordinary as they were. And it wasnt just festival goers who lost out - people on the island had pulled out all the stops to make sure it was a success. But with the whole thing being put together in just six to eight weeks, the signs it wasnt going to be success it promised were there from the start. And when party goers started to descend on the island, the whole thing fell into chaos.  After being promised a private jet and luxury limos to take them to the venue, people were in fcat transported to the island on a charter flight and picked up at the airport by bus. And when they arrived it was described as like something out of The Hunger Games.Seth, who writes on Twitter as William Needham Finley IV, said: Fyre Fest is a complete disaster. No organisation. No one knows where to go.There are no villas, just a disaster tent city. Furniture bought to transform the tents into a luxury experience turned out to be flatpack and was lying around the site, waiting to be built. Luggage dumped in the car park couldnt be reunited with owners and even the bars and the food stalls hadnt been set up. It has been reported people started looting the boxes of food and drink - and then even the piles of luggage. But then things got even worse. Organisers sent an email saying the festival was cancelled and everyone would have to be flown off the island. Seth told the BBC: Theres so much more to the story than rich kids of Instagram meets Lord of the Flies.Workers on the island also werent paid for the time. And the island locals also massively lost out with one restaurant owner stumping up pound, of her le savings to cater for the festival. Chris Smith, who directed the Netflix documentary, told the BBC: She put up her savings to try and live up to the obligations she had made to them. In the end, when things fell apart and everyone just left, she was left having to deal with this.  Prosecutors called McFarland the consummate con artist in a sentencing memorandum according to the NYC Times. He betrayed and deceived his investors, customers, and employees while he was living the high le at his luxury apartment, traveling to exclusive locales, staying at luxury hotels, being chauffeured in his Maserati, and entertaining himself and his friends at restaurants, bars, and casinos, they added. McFarland begged U.S. District Court Judge Naomi Buchwald for leniency and said Im sorry several times during his sentencing hearing. He claimed he had faced violence in prison and said: The best way to be sorry is through my future actions.

story: NewsBritish family stranded at ski resort by ft wall of snow freed by lorriesAnthony Gibbon, from Carmarthenshire, Wales, was on a family holiday in Ischgl, western Austria, when things took a turn for the worstShareCommentsByHannah DoddVideo Journalist:,  JAN Newsthis.style.displaynone"Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror video watch-lorry-breaks-through-ft-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:, combinedPrompt :true, subsets :[,,,,,],bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,swipeNavigation:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:, combinedPrompt :true, subsets :[,,,,,],bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,swipeNavigation:true""Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA British family became stranded on their ski resort by a ft high snow drt this week.Anthony Gibbon, from Carmarthenshire, Wales, was on a family holiday in Ischgl, western Austria, when things took a turn for the worst.Conditions in the area grew so treacherous that guests were faced with trekking through dense snow and ice to get to safety, as roads were left totally snowed in. But help would come from a very unlikely source for the Gibbon family - a group of lorry drivers to be precise.  The drivers, who were also desperate to clear the roads to make deliveries, began clearing away huge blocks of ice, like giant snow plows. Talking about the surreal experience, Gibbon said: I was shocked because we had to leave [where we were staying] and as you could see it was an impossible mission. [My two] kids, on the other hand, were laughing and enjoying the snow. Since the snow was huge, we had to exit from behind where people who work at that [truck] depot or whatever it is were cleaning snow and they cleared a path for us.When we got out we had to wait for the road to be cleared fully so we waited there for two hours. Mr Gibbons footage shows the lorries shuffling through the thick snow, leaving a rectangular impression just deep enough to allow vehicles in and out.  Press in Austria have reported that the extreme weather conditions have affected both locals and tourists, with up to , people left cut off from the outside world. Snowstorms have covered parts of central Europe over the last week, andthe forecast is correct Britain could be also in for a big freeze in the coming days.

title: ex fbi agent who exposed
story: NewsEx-FBI agent who exposed IRA terrorists lives in constant fear of assassinationEXCLUSIVE: Maureen Rupert and her husband captured IRA leader Michael McKevittShareByRhian Lubin:,  JAN Updated:,  JAN NewsMaureen Rupert and David Rupert in an Irish pub"Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailMaureen Rupert lives in Midwestern USA. We can’t know exactly where but we know she is always looking over her shoulder for a Real IRA assassin. Her husband David was a senior member of the Republican group, while a double agent for the FBI and MI, with Maureen undercover, too. So trusted was the American – nicknamed the Big Yank for his ft in, -stone build – that he was appointed to the terrorists’ elite Army Council.He was not only let in on a plot to assassinate then prime minister Tony Blair but even charged with acquiring the weaponry to carry out the attack.When he gave evidence against the Real IRA’s chief of staff, blamed for the horric  Omagh bombing, it led to Michael McKevitt being jailed.   Maureen says: “When it went to court, it blew our lives up. I don’t know how he did it or how I did it. But I believe we saved so many lives. “We got Michael McKevitt and I am very, very proud of David for that.” The US couple’s story is told for the first time by Irish journalist Sean O’Driscoll in The Accidental Spy. Maureen met trucking firm boss David in August , when he rented an office at the truck stop she ran. David was a regular visitor to Ireland and was friends with many IRA sympathisers, having been introduced to the community by an ex who raised funds in the US for the terror group. That summer, David took Maureen with him for the first time. She recalls walking into a pub in Donegal where the walls were covered in IRA posters. “It was all threatening stuff,” she says. “And women were coming in with prams and dancing around singing all these IRA rebel ballads. I thought, ‘Jesus, what is this ’”   David’s regular transatlantic trips did not go unnoticed. He had already been approached by the FBI to work for them. The night they ed to Chicago he told Maureen they had now offered to pay him to be an undercover agent. At that point the former wrestler agreed only to milk the FBI. David says: “I thought, ‘Hey,I can sucker the FBI into paying for our trips, great.’ We both loved Ireland. I didn’t know anything anyway.” It wasn’t long before the MI also wanted him on their books.  Maureen, who became David’s fourth we in November , says: “At the time I thought it was all very James Bond. After  years as a woman in the trucking business, nothing scared me. It was exciting andthe FBI pay for us, great. “Looking back, I had no idea how deep into this thing we would go.” As the peace process progressed, before culminating in the Good Friday Agreement in April , terrorists on both sides gave up their weapons. But the Real IRA splinter group refused. These were the people Maureen and David had befriended. “These people would kill us in a secondthey knew the truth,” Maureen says. “One day I said to David, ‘I can’t wait until we have a normal le’. And he says, ‘You know it will never be a normal le’.” They had a system where immediately after David met with terrorists, he would recite to her what occurred and she’d write it down. Maureen says: “I would give David the notes, then he’d email encrypted details of the meetings to MI and the FBI.” They then burned the notes in the sink. They became so trusted by the IRA that they were invited to dinners with McKevitt and his we Bernadette Sands-McKevitt – sister of Republican Bobby Sands, who died on hunger strike in Maze jail, Co Down, in .  The Ruperts’ double le was thrilling at times but having to lie to their families was exhausting. Maureen says: “It was draining, we lived in a dferent world. My dad, who would’ve been in his s, two brothers and a sister all thought David was in the IRA running guns.” And they came close to being found out. After meeting with an FBI agent in Ireland, David discovered the man had left his business card. Had it been found by the IRA, David would have been killed. He said: “I knew the FBI had this rule: never flush anything down a toilet unless you flush it three times because it can float back up again. So I took the card and ate it.” To prove his loyalty, David smuggled cash into Ireland from Republican sympathisers in the US. He became known as “the man with the bag of money from Chicago” after offering to help Chicago’s Irish Freedom Committee, who funded arms for the IRA. David was later appointed to the Real IRA’s Army Council, rubbing shoulders with bombers.McKevitt would discuss with himhow he wanted to secure sophisticated weapons and said big attacks would soon happen in England.He told David about an “excellent” assassin in Boston who he wanted to target “Tony Blair or somebody of that calibre”. Soon, authorities were urging David to give evidence against the terrorists in court. He refused. A turning point was the Real IRA’s Omagh bomb, which killed  people in the worst atrocity of the Troubles since they began in the late s. Maureen, based in Bundoran, Co Donegal, at the time, says: “We were reeling.  “I remember David coming home, I never saw anyone pack so fast. “We went to the airport and flew to Edinburgh to fly to London, just to get back to the US. We just had to get out of there. It was terrible. “When they asked us to testy, we decided it wouldn’t be a good thing to do. Then all of a sudden we saw a broadcast of the Omagh bombing. “It showed these poor kids, body parts everywhere. David looked at me and said, ‘We have to testy’.” In  David took the stand at McKevitt’s trial in Dublin. McKevitt was convicted of directing terrorism and membership of the IRA, and jailed for  years. David was accompanied out of Dublin by SAS bodyguards and flown out on a Hercules transport aircraft. McKevitt, now , was released in . Maureen says: “We lost some sleep but now our fear isn’t so much McKevitt. “There are a lot of sympathisers in Boston and Chicago who’d love to do us harm they want the badge saying they got Rupert.” David received almost poundmillion from the Federal Rewards for Justice fund. In  he was paid a final sum from the MI. O’Driscoll claims it is about pound,. In all, he received about pound.million from authorities. Yet the couple are both on prescription medication for anxiety and depression. In spite of this, Maureen says: “I would love to go back to Ireland but I don’t think it would ever be possible.”
